<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_from_buffer_copy:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_buffer_copy (size_t size,
                                      const void *buffer)
{
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  void *mhd_copy;

  if (0 == size)
    return MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls (0,
                                                                   NULL,
                                                                   NULL,
                                                                   NULL);
  if (NULL == buffer)
    return NULL;

  mhd_copy = malloc (size);
  if (NULL == mhd_copy)
    return NULL;
  memcpy (mhd_copy, buffer, size);

  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls (size,
                                                              mhd_copy,
                                                              &free,
                                                              mhd_copy);
  if (NULL == r)
    free (mhd_copy);
  else
  {
    /* TODO: remove the next assignment, the buffer should not be modifiable */
    r->data_buffer_size = size;
  }

  return r;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
/* TODO: remove the next assignment, the buffer should not be modifiable */
    r->data_buffer_size = size;
explanation: Fragments not listed were not selected because they do not present obvious pointer-to-non-const issues relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13: the function parameter is already declared as const (const void *buffer) so it conforms to the rule at the call site; early-return checks (if (0 == size), if (NULL == buffer), NULL checks on malloc) and the free() call placement are control-flow/error-handling and not pointer-qualification issues; the function return type and local variable 'r' are structures/pointers to mutable response objects where non-const is expected; the use of memcpy and malloc themselves are fine per se, but the destinations/usages of the allocated buffer (declared above) are the primary places where const-qualification should be reviewed — those are included in the suspicious fragments. No other pointer declarations or uses in the shown code suggest a missing const qualification.
